head.title: Democrats Aid Reagan In Acid-Rain Inaction

hedline.hl1: Democrats Aid Reagan In Acid-Rain Inaction

block.p: With regard to ''Talking While Acid Rains'' (editorial, April 7), it should be pointed out that President Reagan is not alone when it comes to foot dragging on this issue. The chairman of the House committee that oversees acid rain legislation, John D. Dingell of Detroit, opposes any legislation that would force car makers to adhere to stricter exhaust-emissions standards. The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, from coal-producing West Virginia, opposes any measure that requires power plants to burn less sulfur-rich coal.

Acid rain is an important issue to the Northeast and to Canada. However, support of or opposition to reducing it cannot be defined along political party lines. In your haste to blast the Reagan Administration you fail to acknowledge that the issue is enveloped in home-state politics, and that Democratic opposition toward legislation aimed at reducing acid rain exists. It is this Democratic opposition that is undermining efforts toward passage of comprehensive acid-rain legislation which is far more worthy of your editorial attention. DAVID J. PARK Port Chester, N.Y., April 9, 1987
